metadata.title: Nonlinear thermo-electromechanical vibration analysis of size-dependent functionally graded flexoelectric nano-plate-exposed magnetic field

sections.text: Keywords Flexoelectric theory · Nonlinear free vibration · Functionally graded behavior · Size effect · Static magnetic field

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text:
In the recent years, a new type of smart materials known as magneto-electro-elastic (MEE) materials has been considered by many researchers due to their magnetic and electrical properties associated with each other [1]. Given the effect of electrical, magnetic and mechanical fields on each other that do not exist separately in piezoelectric and piezomagnetic materials, magneto-electro-elastic structures had particular importance in the manufacturing of smart equipment. These composite materials have two piezoelectric and piezomagnetic components that can convert magnetic, electrical or mechanical energy to each other [2–5].
MEE nanomaterials have a higher magnetoelectric coefficient thanMEE bulk composite materials [6]. This means that in the MEE nanomaterials, external magnetic fields have a greater effect on the induced potential
A. Ghobadi Mechanical Engineering Department, Shahrekord University, Shahrekord, Iran
Y. T. Beni · H. Golestanian Faculty of Engineering, Shahrekord University, Shahrekord, Iran
Y. T. Beni (B) Nanotechnology Research Center, Shahrekord University, Shahrekord, Iran E-mail: tadi@eng.sku.ac.ir
difference and the electric field, and for external electrical potential, it will also have a greater effect on the potential difference and the created magnetic field.
The higher magneto-electric coefficient of the material in smaller scales and higher surface-to-volume ratios lead to MEE materials have more applicable in many technological fields such as vibration control, sensors, actuators, medical equipment, robotics, energy absorbents and sensitive medical devices [7,8]. Then, nanoscale structures such as nano-beams, nano-shells, nano-plates, and nanotubes have been used extensively in some cases including measurement equipment, medicine and industry and have led many scientists to pay special attention at nanotechnology and nano-science [9–14].
Due to the sensitivity and accuracy of the nano-structure performance, these devices can be used in the industry for such applications as the manufacturing of nano-sensors [15], nano-actuators, nano-vibrators [16] and nano-composites and play a very important role in the behavior of magneto-electromechanical systems [17–21].
For the first time in 1970, a magneto-electro-elastic composite with piezoelectric and piezomagnetic properties was constructed [1]. In the last 10 years, due to the wide application of MEE materials (such as BiFeO3BaTiO3-COFe2O4-NiFeO4-PZT) in very small scales and nano-structures made of them (such as nanowires, nano-plates), these materials were attracted the attention of many researchers [22–25].
When the scale of the structure tends to nano, atomic experiments and simulations have shown that mechanical properties, piezoelectric, piezomagnetic and magnetoelectric coefficients of MEE materials are initially dependent on the structure size [26–28]. So that for studying the electro-magneto-mechanical behavior of MEE nano-materials, the effects of size in laboratory investigations and theory studies should be taken into consideration, and in micro and higher scales, the role of this effect will be greatly reduced [29].
Materials with an asymmetric molecular structure that can be electrically bipolarized in response to uniform mechanical strain are known as piezoelectric materials. All dielectric materials with symmetric center crystalline arrangement under non-uniform mechanical strains field or strain gradient field are electrically polarized, and the electrical potential is induced in them. This electromechanical effect, first discovered and introduced by Kogan in 1960, was called the flexoelectricity phenomenon [30].
The direct effect of this phenomenon is more applied on the sensors and when the energy absorption has particular importance for the nano-plate. The inverse effect of the flexoelectric phenomenon applies in extra-precision operators and controlling the robots. In addition, other examples of the application of direct effect of this phenomenon in nano-structures are: electron microscopes, lighters and energy absorbing shoes for soldiers and tennis rackets. Controlling the robot arm position is one of the applications of the inverse effect of the flexoelectric phenomenon [31].
For the first time, Kogan estimated the flexoelectricity coefficient for some dielectrics with various crystal arrangements that (e/a) ratio of them was 10−9 (c/m) approximately. In his study, e is the generated electric charge and a is related to the crystal lattice parameters [32].
Marangati et al. estimated theflexoelectric coefficients of somedielectrics usinggeneral flexoelectric theory. They theoretically and experimentally demonstrated that the crystal structure symmetry of the piezoelectric materials is demolished by applying the non-uniform strain on the material and electrical dipoles are generated in them [33].
Considering the flexoelectric effect, the size effect and the electrostatic force, the electrical enthalpy energy in nano-dielectrics was determined and developed by Shen and Hu using variation’s principle. They considered the electrostatic stress in two parts. The first part consists of terms related to polarization andmechanical strain, and the second part consists of terms related to polarization gradient and mechanical strain gradients [34].
Li et al. introduced a new formulation for flexoelectricity theory in order to study the electromechanical behavior of flexoelectric materials and improved the internal energy function for isotropic materials. In this formulation, the mechanical strain gradient tensor has been split into two other independent tensors in two modes. By introducing this theory, the high-order constants related to the strain gradient tensor were decreased to three, and only the dilatation gradient tensors and the semi-symmetric part of the deviatoric rotary gradient tensor express the relationship between strain gradient and electrical polarization [35].
According to the previous studies, the classical continuum mechanic theories have low precision in analyzing the electromechanical behavior of the nano-structures and have several defects [36]. In these theories, the empty space between the atoms and the bonds between the particles have not be considered against physics and main dimensions. Therefore, in order to investigate the behavior of nano-structures more accurately, other methods such as laboratory methods and molecular dynamics method should be used [37].
Since these methods are suitable for materials with a small number of atoms in their structure, they are also costly and time-consuming. In recent years several non-classical elasticity theories such as non-local elasticity
theory, modified strain gradient elasticity theory andmodified coupled stress theory were suggested. In order to investigate the accuracy of these methods, some researchers were employed them to study buckling, vibration and static bending of the small size structures [38–43]. In these theories, the size effects have been considered in nano- and microscale structures. Among these theories, the non-local elasticity theory has wide application due to its simplicity and proper application in the study of the nonlinear behavior of micro- and nano-structures and its consistency with the results of molecular dynamics.
Since MEE materials have unique properties and have been frequently used in the manufacture of sensors and actuators,many scientists have studied the behavior of thesematerials using theoretical analysis. Therefore, various numerical and theoretical studies have been carried out to study the static and dynamic performance characteristics of these nano-structures. Also, the stability of multilayer equipment made of these materials has been investigated using numerous numerical methods such as state vector theory [44–48] and transformation matrix method [49,50].
In order to investigate the behavior of MEE materials, various analyses and numerical studies were performed. Some of them are about investigation of the static deformations [51,52], free vibrations [53,54] and the linear dynamic response of these materials [55,56].
Li, using the Mindlin’s theory, examined the buckling of MEE nano-plate resting on an elastic foundation. UsingMaxwell equations andmagneto-electric boundary conditions, he determined the electrical andmagnetic potential along the nano-plate thickness and extracted the governing equations of the nano-plate buckling behavior using the variation’s method. The results of this study showed that by increasing the lateral load, the critical buckling load is decreased and increasing non-local parameter of critical buckling load results in a decrease in the free vibration frequencies [57].
Liu et al. investigated the free vibrations of a piezoelectric nano-plate using non-local elasticity theory and Kirchhoff plate theory for thermo-electromechanical loadings. The results of this study indicated that increasing the non-local parameters reduced the natural frequencies of nano-plate and the electrical loadings significantly influenced on the natural frequencies and thermal loadings do not have major effect on them [58].
Li et al. studied the size-dependent static bending and free vibrations of an Euler–Bernoulli nano-beam using the flexoelectric theory proposed by Hadjesfandiari [59]. In their study, a three-layer size-dependent Euler–Bernoulli beam model was introduced to study the piezoelectric and size effect. The results showed that by decreasing the size parameter (h/l), the generated electric potential in the beam and its transverse displacement in the mode of inverse flexoelectric effect will decrease and with increasing the flexoelectric coefficient, these two quantities will increase [60].
Ke et al. determined the size-dependent natural linear frequencies of a MEE nano-plate by using nonlocal elasticity theory. In their study, the free vibrations of nano-plate were investigated using the Kirchhoff plate theory and the governing equations and related boundary conditions by the Hamilton’s principle were derived. The results demonstrated that mechanical loadings and magnetic potential have significant effect and temperature increase would have a negligible effect on natural frequencies [61].
Liang and Shen studied the electromechanical behavior of a piezoelectric nanowire considering the size effect by introducing an Euler–Bernoulli beam model [62]. This new model was based on the theory proposed by Hu and Shen [63].
Using non-local elasticity theory, Li et al. conducted the buckling analysis and free vibrations of the magneto-electro-elastic nano-plate on elastic foundation. In their study, the effects of electrical potential, magnetic field and shear and elastic coefficients of elastic foundation on the buckling and vibrational behavior of the nano-plate were investigated [64].
Liu and Chang analytically investigated the vibration and bending of transverse isotropic MEE rectangular plate by using Kirchhoff thin plate theory. The governing equations of the plate behavior that are in terms of transverse displacement components were obtained by using Hamilton’s principle. The natural frequencies of MEE plate were analytically determined, and the effect of volume fraction on them was investigated [65].
Farajpour et al. examined the nonlinear free vibrations depending on the size effects of a MEE nano-plate by using non-local continuum elasticity model. According to the presented results, the nonlinear frequency ratio values obtained using the non-local plate theory are larger than its values from classical non-local plate theory. Considering the non-local parameter in the compatibility equations, the frequency ratio will be reduced [66].
Razavi and Shooshtari studied the nonlinear vibrations of a symmetrical layer MEE rectangular plate with four simply support edges. In order to determine the motion equations, they used Von Karman’s nonlinear strains and first-order shear deformation theory. The results illustrated that the nonlinear frequency ratio of
the plate was reduced by applying the magneto-electro-elastic layer. Also, the length-to-thickness ratio in comparison with the length-to-width ratio had a very insignificant influence on the frequency values [67].
Wang et al. analyzed the free vibration of the functionally graded material (FGM) beam base on midplane and neutral plane formulation. In order to investigate the two formulations’ accuracy, they compared the obtained results from the two mentioned formulations. It was demonstrated that the obtained results are different when the immovable simple supports are positioned at two different planes. Also, the mid-plane formulation provides the same natural frequencies as the neutral plane formulation in the movable simply supports [68].
Barati studied the vibrations of a nano-beam under the external potential with closed electric circuit considering the surface effects. In order to investigate the behavior of the structure, it was assumed that nano-beam is embedded on an elastic foundation and the differential equations and boundary conditions were derived using Hamilton’s principle. The obtained results illustrated that surface and flexoelectric effects have a significant effect on the nonlinear frequencies of the nano-beam [69].
Liang et al. studied the buckling and vibrations of a flexoelectric nano-plate by using general flexoelectricity theory. They assumed that the nano-plate was subjected to pure mechanical loading. The obtained results showed that the flexoelectric coefficient and nano-plate thickness would have a significant effect on the critical buckling load values and natural frequencies [70].
Considering the flexoelectric phenomenon, Zhang improved and enhanced the magneto-electric effects of composite materials and multiferroic structures using analytical methods. He derived the three-dimensional governing equations of the electromechanical behavior of piezoelectric solids and boundary conditions using flexoelectric theory [71]. Other researchers studied static bending, buckling and vibrations of the nano-beams taking into account the size and flexoelectric effect [72–76].
Tadi Beni et al. performed the analysis of the buckling and size-dependent vibration of the piezoelectric nano-shell under electric and mechanical loadings. They examined such effects as the size effect, flexoelectric effect, external magnetic field, external electric field and different boundary conditions on the magnetoelectromechanical response of the nano-shell [77–80].
Fattahian Dehkordi and Tadi Beni studied the free vibrations of the single-layer piezoelectric nano-cones using coupled stress theory and thin-shell Low model [81].
Mehralian and Tadi Beni investigate the vibration of a bimorph FGP cylindrical nanoshell using the nonlocal strain gradient theory. They considered that the material properties vary along the thickness direction according to power law distribution [82]. Zeighampour and Tadi Beni have developed the cylindrical thin-shell model based on the modified strain gradient theory. They were considered size effects through modified strain gradient theory to develop the thin shell theory [83]. Kheibari and Tadi Beni studied the free vibration of piezoelectric nanotubes based on Love’s cylindrical thin-shell model. In order to investigate the effects of size on the vibration of piezoelectric nanotubes, the consistent couple stress theory is used for piezoelectric nanotubes [84].
Ebrahimi and Barati studied the thermoelectric vibrations of a flexoelectric nano-plate using non-local elasticity theory for different boundary conditions. They considered that the temperature distribution along the nano-plate thickness is in linear and uniform type. The results of the analytical solution illustrated the effect of factors such as flexoelectricity, non-local parameter, surface parameters, temperature increase, nano-plate thickness and different boundary conditions on the vibrations of flexoelectric nano-plate [85].
Shojaeian and Tadi Beni performed the electromechanical buckling of beam-type nano-electromechanical systems by considering the nonlinear geometric effect and intermolecular forces using the modified couple stress theory [86]. Shojaeian et al. investigated the electromechanical buckling of beam-type nanoelectromechanical systems using the modified strain gradient theory. It is taken into account that the beam is made of axially and transverse functionally graded materials [87]. Ghobadi et al. investigated the effects of the flexoelectricity on nonlinear static bending of a functionally graded piezo–flexoelectric nano-plate under thermoelectromechanical loadings. In order to obtain the static bending formulation, the flexoelectric modified and the Kirchhoff classic plate theories were employed [88].
According to thementioned investigations, the buckling and vibrations of flexoelectric nano-structures have been investigated using non-classical theories including coupled stress, strain gradient and non-local elasticity theories. In a new study, Li et al. introduced a new formulation for flexoelectric theory [35]. In this formulation, the strain gradient tensor is divided into two independent parts. These two tensors are dilatation gradient tensors and the non-symmetric part of deviatoric rotary strain gradient tensor that indicate the relationship between strain gradient and polarization. The flexoelectrically modified theory has advantages and disadvantages in comparison with other non-classical theories. Among the benefits, simple formulation and the relationship
between the electrical and mechanical parts can be mentioned. Studying the previous researches, it can be found that using modified flexoelectric theory, nonlinear vibrational behavior of flexoelectric nano-plate under magneto-thermo–electro–mechanical loadings has not been yet investigated. In this paper, the nonlinear free vibrations of flexoelectric nano-plate have been investigated under different boundary conditions and loading types with the multiple-scale method. It can be concluded that the novelties of this paper are:
First the newcoupled thermo-electromagnetic formulation has been proposed to investigate theflexoelectric nano-plates. Second nonlinear vibration analysis has been utilized for flexoelectric nano-plates using the perturbation method. Third functionally graded material has been studied with consideration of the flexoelectric effect. Fourth the effects of the temperature rise on the electromechanical response of flexoelectric nano-plate have been considered. Fifth the effects of different boundary conditions have been considered in the present study. Sixth behavior of nonlinear free vibrations of nano-plate in both direct and inverse flexoelectric effects has been conducted.

sections.heading: 2 New formulation of the modified flexoelectric theory
sections.text:
The general expression of internal energy density function for dielectric materials, which is a function of the strain, strain gradient, polarization and its gradient, is introduced in previous researches [35].
Due to the presence of an electric field, the internal energy density function is a function of polarization and its gradient. Thus, adding the effect of the magnetic field, this function is reformulated in the following equation.
U = 1 2 Ci jklεi jεkl + 1 2 gi jklmnηi jkηlmn
+ 1 2 αi j .Pi Pj + 1 2 bE i jkl Qi j Qkl + eEi jkl Qi jεkl + f Ei jkl Piη jkl + di j Pi B j − γ E i Pi T + 1 2 mi j .Bi B j + 1 2 bM i jkl Si j Skl + eMi jkl Si jεkl + f Mi jkl Biη jkl + di j Bi Pj − γ M i Bi T .
(1)
Ci jkl is fourth-order elastic constants tensor, εi j is strain tensor, gi jklmn is purely non-local elastic effects, ηi jk is strain gradient tensor, αi j is second-order reciprocal dielectric susceptibility tensor, Pi is polarization vector, and bEi jkl is fourth-order tensor expressing the effect of electrical polarization gradient [35].
Qi j is a polarization gradient tensor, eEi jkl , f E i jkl are flexoelectric tensors, di j is tensor of second order magnetoelectric coefficients, Bi is magnetic flux density vector, and γ Ei is modified pyroelectric coefficients. Also, T is temperature variations along the plate thickness, mi j is second-order reciprocal magnetic tensor, bMi jkl is the tensor expressing the effects of magnetic flux density gradient, Sij is tensor of magnetic flux density gradient, eMi jkl , f M i jkl are flexomagnetic coefficients tensor, and γ M i is modified pyromagnet coefficients.
eEi jkl and f E i jkl are flexoelectric tensors, and according to the Lifshits invariant rule fi jkl .(Pi ηi jk−Qi jεkl) presented by Eliseev [89], relations eEi jkl = − f Ei jkl and eMi jkl = − f Mi jkl can be written. According to thefindings of previous studies [71,90,91], formodified pyroelectric coefficients andmodified pyromagnetic coefficients, relations γ Ei = (αi j )pEi and γ Mi = (mi j )pMi are presented, respectively [90,92]. αi j is determined based on the relation αi j = (ai j )−1, so that ai j is the second-order dielectric tensor [90]. Also,mij is determined using the relationmi j = (μi j )−1, whereμi j is the second-order magnetic permeability tensor [92]. ai j and μi j are the diagonal tensors. The superscripts E and M in all relationships are related to electrical and magnetic effects, respectively.
As the structure of the material is assumed to be isotropic in this study, the tensor bMi jkl is similar to the
tensor bEi jkl and the tensors f M i jk , di j , mi j are described as follows [35]:
mi j = mδi j , di j = dδi j , (2) f Mi jkl = f M1 δi jδkl + f M2 (δikδ jl + δilδ jk). (3)
The constants m and d are reciprocal magnetic permeability coefficients and the magnetoelectric coefficients along the nano-plate thickness.
Adding the magnetic and thermal terms to the obtained energy function, the constitutive equations are obtained as follows:

Also, in the above relation, eijk, α and k are permutation tensor, dielectric constant along the thickness direction and volume modulus, respectively.
Parameters li , βEi andβ M i are length scale parameters related to the strain gradient, the electrical polarization gradient and the magnetic polarization gradient, respectively. Also, the quantities m′i j , τ (1) i jk , pi are tensors related to dilation gradient γi , deviatoric stretch gradient tensor η (1) i jk and deviatoric rotation gradient tensor χ ′i j , respectively. In the above relations, βi j is a thermal moduli tensor and is defined as follows:
βi j = Ci jklαTkl . (5)

According to the previous descriptions, the energy density function is finally written as follows [34]:
U = 1 2 σi jεi j + 1 2 τ (1) i jk η (1) i jk + 1 2 piγi + 1 2 m′i jχ ′i j + 1 2 Ei Pi + 1 2 Vi j Qi j + 1 2 Hi Bi + 1 2 Zi j Si j . (7)

Equations (36) to (38) and Eqs. (41) to (43) are six couple magneto-thermo-electrical motion equations. Using the solution methods presented in the following, these six couple equations can be solved. Thus, the natural mode shapes, generated electrical and magnetic field, generated electrical and magnetic bipolar and the natural frequencies of the nano-plate will be determined. In Eqs. (41) to (43), the parameter βE is presented as:
β2E = √( βE1 )2 + (βE2 )2 + (βE3 )2. (44) The constants parameters in Eqs. (41) to (43) include αa , da , ( f E1 )a , ( f M 1 )a , (γ E 3 )a , (γ M 3 )a , ma are reciprocal dielectric constant, magnetoelectric coefficient, flexoelectric coefficient, flexomagnetic coefficient, pyroelectric coefficient, pyromagnetic coefficient and reciprocal magnetic constant of the FG nano-plate along the thickness direction, respectively. These parameters are determined using the following equation:
(M)a = 1h h−z̄c∫ −z̄c [ (M)2 + ((M)1 − (M)2) ( z + z̄c h )n̂] dz. (45)
In order to solve the motion equations (36) to (38), first the electromagnetic governing equations (Eqs. (41) to (43)) have to be solved. These equations are solved using the electromagnetic boundary conditions presented in Eq. (33) and the boundary conditions related to the direct and inverse flexoelectric effects, which is given in the next section. Therefore, the electrical and magnetic polarization functions, the electrical potential, the magnetic flux density and linear and nonlinear natural frequencies of the nano-plates are determined.
In this study, it was assumed that the nano-plate can has three support types. These edges were considered as simply–simply–simply–simply support (SSSS), clamped–clamped–clamped–clamped support (CCCC) and a combination of both as two opposite edges simply and two other edges clamped support that are presented as simply–clamped–simply–clamped support (SCSC). The classical and non-classical boundary conditions for the nano-plates with boundary conditions SSSS, SCSC and CCCC are expressed in all edges in Eqs. (46), (47) and (48), respectively.

sections.heading: 4 Free vibrations analysis in direct flexoelectric effect
sections.text:
In this section, the behavior of functionally graded nano-plates is determined by assuming a mechanical load of zero (free vibrations). First, as it is referred to, the differential equations (41)–(43) are solved using the given electromagnetic boundary conditions (Eq. 50). For direct flexoelectric effect, the electrical boundary conditions are proposed inRef. [35]. Therefore, in the direct flexoelectric effect, electric andmagnetic boundary conditions are considered as follows [96]:
at z = −z̄c, h − z̄c, V33 = 0, D3 = 0, at z = −z̄c, ϕ = 0, B3 = nM B0, at z = h − z̄c, B3 = B0. (50)
Since BaTiO3 and PZT-5H are paramagnetic materials, the amplification of the magnetic field along the nano-plate thickness direction is low. Also, due to the nano-plate dimensions which are in nanoscales, the amplification amount of this field will be less than micro- and higher dimensions. Therefore, the magnetic field density emanating from the nano-plate lower surface is slightly higher than the one from the upper surface. The constant nM can be between 1.01 and 1.05 [92]. In this study, this constant is considered as 1.01.
Solving the differential equations (41)–(43) and using the boundary conditions [relations (33) and (50)], the polarization functions P3(z), the electrical potential ϕ(z) and the magnetic potential ψ(z) are determined as follows:
P3(x, y, z) = A1 (x, y) + A2 (x, y) egE z + A3 (x, y) e−gE z − REz g2E , (51)

sections.heading: 5 Free vibrations analysis in inverse flexoelectric effect
sections.text:
In this section, the nonlinear frequencies of the nano-plate are determined when the plate is subjected to the external and constant voltage V0 and the static magnetic flux density B0 along the thickness. Considering the boundary conditions given in Eq. (62), the differential equation systems (41)–(43) are solved. Thus, the polarization functions P3(z) and the electrical potential ϕ(z) are determined.
Due to the nano-plate is subjected to the external potential V0 in the inverse flexoelectric effect case, the presented electrical boundary conditions in Ref. [35] were used. Therefore, in the inverse flexoelectric effect, the magnetic and electrical boundary conditions are taken into account as follows [96]:

sections.heading: 6 Solution method (multiple-scale method)
sections.text:
According to the previous studies, the presented approximate methods are generally not suitable for exact or semi-analytic solution of motion equations of the nonlinear vibrational systems. In the dynamic analysis of these kinds of systems, the terms that are greatly increased over time and cause to divergence of some of the physical quantities of the system are considered. Therefore, these terms should not be existed in the time responses of such systems and are known as secular terms [100].
Due to the eliminating this type of terms in the dynamic response of nonlinear vibrational systems, the multiple-scale semi-analytical method can be used as a powerful method among the methods related to the perturbation theory.
Expanding the unknown independent parameter that is time dependent, it is written in terms of several unknown independent parameters and a very short dimensionless parameter ε and is embedded in the motion equations. Writing the coefficients of the terms ε0, ε1, ε2, etc. several ordinary couple differential equations are obtained. Eliminating the secular terms, the motion equations will be solved with the remaining elements.
In the analysis of nonlinear vibrations of flexoelectric nano-plates, the multiple-scale method has been used to determine the natural frequencies. The following relations are used to non-dimensionalize the motion equations.

In order to solve the obtained couple differential equations and determination of the frequencies and the natural modes shapes, the Galerkin’s method has been used.
The employing process of this method on the obtained differential equations is as follows. By multiplying both sides of the motion equations in u0(x, y, z, t), v0(x, y, z, t) and w(x, y, z, t) and integration over the plate cross section with respect to x and y, the governing differential equations can be obtained only in terms of the variable z. Given that the previous constants are multiplied in time-independent terms of the displacement components as u0(x, y, z, t), v0(x, y, z, t) and w(x, y, z, t), the final obtained constants are determined and presented as A1i, B1i, C1i.
It should be noted that in this study, the transverse vibrations of the functionally graded nano-plate are intended. Therefore, the inertia terms related to the in-plane vibrations of plate (q̈1(t), q̈2(t)) are not considered. sections.heading: 7 Results and discussion
sections.text:
In this study, the nonlinear free vibrations of a functionally graded flexoelectric nano-plate have been studied using a new formulation of the modified flexoelectric theory. Nano-plate has different boundary conditions and is under thermal, magnetic and electrical loadings. The results are obtained for both direct and inverse flexoelectric effects.
In this section, the performance characteristics of the free vibrations of the nano-plate, such as the nonlinear natural frequencies and the natural mode shapes for different boundary conditions and various loadings, were determined and the obtained results are presented in some tables and plots. In addition, the influence of the parameters such as plate thickness, length-to-width ratio, index of the FGM model, mechanical and electrical length scale parameter (li and βi ), magnetic potential difference and magnetic flux density on vibrational behavior of nano-plate has been investigated.
In order to validate the results of this study, the obtained results are compared to those of similar studies in previous researches. In the free vibrations analysis of the nano-plate, it has been assumed that the upper surface of nano-plate is made of pure barium titanate material and the lower surface of the nano-plate is made of pure PZT-5H material. The mechanical, electrical, thermal and magnetic properties of these two materials are given in Table 1 [93–95]. In most of the results, length scale parameters associated with the strain gradient (li ) and electric polarization gradient (βEi ) are considered as follows: l0 = l1 = l2 = l = 3 × 10−8 (m).
In this study, it was assumed that all length scale parameters associated with the electric polarization gradient (βEi ) and the magnetic polarization gradient (β M i ) are equal to 1.
PZT-5H material is made of the compositions consisting of the lead oxide, titanium dioxide and zirconium dioxide (zirconium) compounds. Lead oxide and titanium dioxide are paramagnetic, and zirconium dioxide is a diamagnetic material. Due to that the PZT-5H magnetic properties are not existed in the previous studies and have not yet been determined experimentally, an acceptable value should be considered for magnetic permeability coefficients of this material.
Since one of the compounds of this material is diamagnetism, the magnetic permeability coefficients of this material can be considered slightly lower than the coefficients of the barium titanium. Therefore, these coefficients are assumed to be 1.5e − 6 and 2.2e − 6 along the x- and the z-directions, respectively. In given figures, the FGM index (n̂) is presented as (n).
7.1 Results validation
In this section, the accuracy of the performed analysis in this study has been investigated by comparing the obtained results with those of the previous studies. According to the previous researches, so far, scientists have not investigated the free vibrations of functionally graded flexoelectric nano-plates under thermal, magnetic and electrical loadings using flexoelectrically modified theory.
Therefore, using a new theory in the analysis of the free vibrations of this nano-plate, addition of magnetic and thermal loads and consideration of the functionally graded behavior of the nano-plate are considered as innovation items in this study. In order that comparing possibility of the obtained results to those of similar studies and according to the mentioned points, it has been assumed that the nano-plate has no magnetic and thermal loadings and the nano-plate is not a functionally graded type.
For this purpose, an analysis conducted by Yang et al. [102] was considered for the comparison and validation of the obtained results. Yang et al. studied the free vibrations of flexoelectric nano-plate using general piezoelectric theory for PZT-5H material. In order to compare the provided results to those of results from Ref. [102], it has been assumed that the nano-plate is made of PZT-5H and n̂ was considered as zero for this purpose. In this model, the flexoelectric nano-plate is under electric loadings with SSSS boundary condition.
In Fig. 2, the natural frequency variations in terms of the (a/h) ratios were plotted in vibration modes (1,1) using the general piezoelectric theory [102] and the theory used in this study. In this model, it was assumed that the length-to-width ratio (a/b) is constant and thermal loadings have not been applied on the nano-plate.
According to Fig. 2, it can be found that results of the present study are consistent to the above-mentioned reference results for natural frequency changes in a/h ratio under similar conditions. It should be noted, however, that there is little difference in the responses due to the difference in how the flexoelectricity coefficient is applied in this study and in the reference [102].
7.2 Material and geometrical parameters study
In this section, the natural frequencies of the functionally graded flexoelectric nano-plate were determined under electric, thermal and magnetic loadings. In order to investigate the behavior of free vibrations, it has been assumed that the nano-plate has various boundary condition such as SSSS, SCSC, and CCCC types. Also, in the various presented models in this study, it has been assumed that the temperature of the upper surface is constant and the temperature of the lower surface is variable. In addition, the static magnetic field is applied on the nano-plate and crosses from the upper toward the lower surface along the nano-plate thickness. In order to determine the vibrational behavior of the nano-plate, such effects as plate dimensions, boundary conditions, temperature variations, the external electric potential, external magnetic field, flexoelectricity parameter, index of functionally graded behavior of the nano-plate and length scale parameter have been investigated.
Since that the flexomagnetic coefficient ( f Mi jkl) tensor of the two materials used in the present study has not been determined experimentally, these coefficients are not found in the previous researches. The number of these coefficients will be reduced to two values for isotropic dielectric. In order to simplify the relations, these two coefficients are considered equal f M1 = f M2 [35]. Both flexomagnetic coefficients for BT are considered to be 20 × 10−7 [N.S/C]. Referring to Table 1, the flexoelectric coefficient of BT is more than the PZT-5H flexoelectric coefficient. Therefore, both flexomagnetic coefficients related to PZT-5Hmaterial can be assumed to be equal to 2 × 10−8 [N.S/C].
Also, it should be noted that in this section, the constant n is the index of the functionally graded behavior of the nano-plate in the presented figures. In all models, it has been assumed that a = b = 50 × h.

sections.heading: 7.2.1 Effects of geometry parameters and different boundary conditions
sections.text:
The first nonlinear dimensionless natural frequency values for different (a/b), (a/h) ratios, different values of the (n̂) and different boundary conditions are presented in Table 2. In this table, the natural frequency values have been determined for V0 = 0.2 (V) and B0 = 0.04 (T) and T2 = 300 (K). In all cases, the dimensionless natural frequency is determined by the following equation:
ω̄i j = ωi j a 2
h
√( ρ
C11 ) 1
(120)
where ρ and C11 are associated with the first material, namely PZT-5H. According to Table 2, it can be indicated that the natural frequencies of nano-plate increased by increasing the index of the nano-plate functionally graded behavior (n̂). This is due to this fact that increasing this index, the material properties are varied from PZT-5H to BaTiO3 and the BaTiO3 material has a higher elastic module than PZT-5H. Therefore, increasing (n̂) from 0 to 50 results an increase in the nano-plate rigidity and its natural frequencies. Also, increasing (a/b) and (a/h) ratios, the frequency values are increased and depend more on (a/b) ratio than (a/h) ratio. If the nano-plate length is considered constant, decreasing the nano-plate thickness, the ratio (a/h) increases. Also, if b is assumed to be constant, (a/b) ratio increases with increasing the nanoplate length (a). Increasing the nano-plate length has a greater effect on the nano-plate rigidity compared to the
thickness reduction. Therefore, increasing the length can have a significant influence on the natural nonlinear frequencies of the nano-plate.
The values of the first four natural dimensionless frequencies for the various boundary conditions are presented in Table 3. In this case, the frequency values are obtained for V0 = 0.1 (V), h = 10 (nm), n̂ = 0.1 and T1 = 300 (K). By increasing the number of the clamped edges, the nano-plate has more resistance against to the transverse vibrations. Therefore, the natural frequency of the nano-plate will also increase, eventually.
In Fig. 3, the first natural frequency changes are plotted in terms of the length-to-thickness ratio of the nano-plate (a/h) for different boundary conditions and various applied electric potentials. In this model, it was assumed that B0 = 0.04 (T), n̂ = 10 and T1 = 300 (K). As illustrated in this figure, the natural frequency of the nano-plate will decrease by increasing the ratio (a/h). This is due to the fact that considering the plate length as a constant, the ratio (a/h) will decrease with increasing the thickness. Thus, for little values of the (a/h) ratios, the second moment of inertia of the nano-plate is increased. Also, its resistance against to the transverse vibrations increases and the natural frequencies of the nano-plate will also increase significantly.
As can be indicated from this figure, the rate of variations in the natural frequency will increase in low values of the (a/h) ratios that occurred at high nano-plate thicknesses.
The reason is that the values of the natural frequencies are higher in more thicknesses and increasing the nano-plate thickness results in an increase in rate of variations of the natural frequencies. The slope of the first natural frequency distributions for the CCCC boundary conditions is more than those for the other boundary conditions, so that, by reducing the number of clamped edges, the rate of changes in the natural frequency changes will also decrease.
By increasing the applied voltage, the values of natural frequencies as well as its rate of the variations will decrease.
In Fig. 4, the first natural frequency variations are plotted in terms of the thickness of the nano-plate for different values of the magnetic flux density and different boundary conditions where length-to-thickness ratio (a/h) is considered to be constant. In this model, it has been assumed that V0 = 0.1 (V), n̂ = 10, T1 = 300 (K).
According to this figure, it can be found that as the thickness of nano-plate increases, the natural frequency values are decreased.
Due to the length-to-thickness ratio (a/h) is considered to be constant, by increasing the thickness of the nano-plate, the length (a) should also be increased. By increasing the flux density of the applied magnetic field on the nano-plate, its natural frequency increases. This behavior in nano-plate is due to the presence of magnetostriction phenomenon in paramagnetic materials. Despite this effect, the mechanical strain along the plate thickness (εz) is slightly increased and the in-plane strains also tend to decrease. Therefore, tensile stresses will be created in the edges of the nano-plate. These induced reactions on the nano-plate edges create an additional resistance against the transverse vibrations of the nano-plate and values of the natural frequencies increase.

sections.heading: 7.2.2 Effects of temperature change
sections.text:
In Table 4, the effects of external electrical potential, temperature of lower surface and the index of the functionally graded behavior of the nano-plate on the first nonlinear natural frequency values are indicated. In this model, V0 = 0.1 (V), h = 10 (nm), B0 = 0.04 (T), and boundary conditions are in SSSS type. Decreasing the amount of (n̂), the nano-plate material changes from BaTiO3 to PZT-5H and the nano-plate rigidity will decrease.
According to Table 4, by reducing the rigidity of the nano-plate, the values of the first natural frequency decrease. Also, increasing the applied electric potential on the nano-plate, the natural frequency of the nanoplate will occur at lower values. In order to justify the effect of the electric potential on the natural frequencies of the nano-plate, the following description can be presented.
By applying the positive or negative voltages, the compressive and tensile forces are created in the nanoplate constraints, respectively. These axial forceswill enhance andweaken the rigidity of the plate, respectively. Increasing the rigidity of the nano-plate results in an increase in natural frequencies. Also, when the rigidity of the nano-plate decreases, the natural frequency values decrease.
By increasing the temperature of the lower surface of the nano-plate, the natural frequency of the free vibrations decrease. This is due to that increasing temperature T1, the nano-plate expands in x–y plane and the length along the x- and y-direction tends to increase in this plane. Expansion of the nano-plate in the x–y plane, the induced compressive reaction force increases on the constraints. Hence, the dimensionless natural frequency reduces, consequently.
According to the values of Table 4, it can be found that the values of the natural frequencies are completely dependent on the applied voltage variations and are not sensitive to temperature variations. So that as voltage changes from −0.2 to 0.2 V, significant changes are observed in the frequency values.
In Table 5, the values of the first four natural frequencies are presented in terms of the different temperatures of the lower surface of the nano-plate for different boundary conditions. In this case, it has been assumed that V0 = 0.1 (V), B0 = 0.04 (T), h = 10 (nm), a = b = 50 × h and n̂ = 10. As noted earlier, the natural frequency of the nano-plate decrease slightly with increasing the temperature, and with increasing the number of fixed edges of nano-plate, the natural frequency will increase significantly.
In Fig. 5, changes in the first four natural dimensionless frequencies are plotted in terms of temperature of lower surface for different thicknesses of the nano-plate. In this model, V0 = 0.1 (V), B0 = 0.04 (T) and h = 10 (nm) have been considered.
As shown in this figure, the natural frequencies will slightly decrease by increasing the temperature. The reason for this fact was explained at the beginning of this section. The variation rates for the higher vibrational modes will be more and for lower vibrational modes will be less.
Also, as mentioned in the previous section, the rate of variation in the natural frequencies will be lower for higher thicknesses and for the lower thicknesses, the trend is inverse.

sections.heading: 7.2.3 Effects of FGM index (n̂)
sections.text:
Table 6 presents the values of four first natural dimensionless frequencies for different nano-plate thicknesses and different values of the index related to functionally graded behavior. In order to determine the values of natural dimensionless frequency, V0 = 0.1 (V), B0 = 0.04 (T), h = 10 (nm) and T1 = 300 (K) are considered. By increasing the index of the functionally graded behavior of the nano-plate, its stiffness increases and natural frequency values increase. Also, increasing the nano-plate thickness results in an increase in the second moment of inertia as well. By increasing the second moment of inertia, the plate’s resistance against the vibration increased and the natural dimensionless frequencies are increased.
The first natural dimensionless frequency changes are plotted in terms of the index related to functionally graded behavior of the nano-plate (n̂) for different thicknesses of the nano-plates and different boundary conditions in Fig. 6. In this figure, it has been assumed that V0 = 0.1 (V), B0 = 0.04 (T), T1 = 300 (K). According to this figure, it can be found that natural frequency increased by increasing (n̂).
By increasing (n̂) from zero to infinity, the nano-plate material changes from PZT-5H to BaTiO3. Due to that the Young modulus for BaTiO3 is greater than PZT-5H, then the elastic modulus of the nano-plate will also increase by increasing (n̂). Increasing the elastic modulus, the rigidity of the nano-plate increased and nano-plate resistance against the transverse vibrations increased. The values of the nano-plate natural frequencies increased with increasing the resistance to the transverse vibrations.
Since the functionally graded behavior of the nano-plate follows the exponential law, in low (n̂) values, frequency has low variation rate and at its high values, the rate of natural frequency variation increases. As mentioned earlier, the natural frequency and variation rate increase as the number of the clamped edges increases.

sections.heading: 7.2.4 Effect of flexoelectricity
sections.text:
Figure 7 shows the natural frequency variations in terms of the nano-plate thickness with and without the presence of a flexoelectric effect for different values of the electric potential and the magnetic flux density. In this model, it has been assumed that h = 10 (nm), n̂ = 10, T1 = 300 (K). With regard to Fig. 8 and the dimensionless frequency equation (Eq. 136), it can be found that increasing the nano-plate thickness, the first dimensionless natural frequencies of the nano-plate decrease.
As previouslymentioned, by increasing the voltage from negative voltage to positive one, the dimensionless natural frequencies decreased and them increased by increasing the magnetic flux density. According to this figure, it can be concluded that two plots for the natural dimensionless frequencies distributions have more difference in two cases with and without the flexoelectric effect for lower thicknesses. As shown in Fig. 7, the
values of the natural frequencies increase in the presence of a flexoelectric effect. Therefore, it can be found that nano-plate rigidity increased in the presence of flexoelectric effect and the nano-plate has more resistant against the transverse vibrations.

sections.heading: 7.2.5 Effect of magnetic flux density on nonlinear vibration
sections.text:
The values of the first dimensionless natural frequency for various applied magnetic flux density and n̂ are given in Table 7. In this case, it has been assumed that V0 = 0.2 (V), h = 5 (nm) and T1 = 300 (K). As shown in this table, increasing the magnetic flux density that applied along the nano-plate thickness, the values
of the natural frequencies increase. Due to the hysteresis curve of the magnetic field induced in the material, the magnetic flux density applied on the nano-plate can be increased to the magnetic saturation point of the structure [92]. This phenomenon is illustrated in hysteresis graph. Due to this graph, the process of reaching the material to magnetic saturation can be observed. If a magnetic material that does not initially have any magnetism is considered, by applying the magnetic field (H), first magnetic dipoles that are more matched to the external magnetic field direction grow until all material dipoles are matched. In this process, the volume of non-matched dipoles decreased. Then, these matched dipoles are completely turned to locate in the same direction of the magnetic field. In this case, the maximum amount of magnetism is observed in the matter. This magnetism is called magnetic saturation.
After reaching the material to the magnetic saturation, decreasing the applied magnetic field, the return path on the saturation graph is not the same as the initial path. When the applied magnetic field become zero, there is still some magnetization inside the material. As the figure shows, due to the presence of a part of the
matched dipoles domains with the external field, there is some magnetism called residual magnetism in the material. Due to the residual magnetism, a little magnetism existed in material without applying the external magnetic field.
If the externalmagnetic field applied in the opposite direction, the residualmagnetismdecreased. Therefore, by increasing this external field, the internal residual magnetism can be tended to zero. After the internal magnetization becomes zero, an inversemagnetism is created in thematerial. Continuing the applyingmagnetic field, the material reaches the inverse magnetic saturation, eventually. The magnitude of this inverse saturation magnetism is exactly the same as direct saturation magnetism except it has a different direction.
By changing the direction of the applying magnetic field (return to the initial direction), the passed path through the magnetic material creates the hysteresis loop.
As the material reaches the magnetic saturation, increasing the magnetic flux density has little effect on the induced magnetic field in it. Therefore, in this study, the magnetic flux density has been increased before the saturation point.
In Fig. 8, the natural frequency variations are shown in terms of the magnetic field density passing through the nano-plate for different boundary conditions and the first four vibrational modes. In this case, it was assumed that h = 10 (nm), V0 = 0.1 (V), n̂ = 10, T1 = 300 (K).
According to this figure, it can be seen that increasing the magnetic flux density increases the natural frequency values. The reason for this fact was explained in Sections 7.2.1. By increasing the clamped edges of the nano-plate, natural frequency values increase. It should be noted that in higher vibrational modes, the rate of natural frequency variation is higher. In higher vibrational modes, the natural frequency values have less variation rates by increasing the clamped edges of the nano-plate.
As shown in Fig. 8, the natural frequencies have lower rates of variation for lower magnetic flux density and increasing the magnetic flux density increases the rate of these variations.

sections.heading: 7.2.6 Investigation nonlinear vibration against linear vibration
sections.text:
Figure 9 shows the changes in first nonlinear natural frequency to the first linear natural frequency ratio in terms of the thickness to the length ratio of the nano-plate (h/a) for different (n̂) values. In this case, it has
been assumed that V0 = 0 (V), B0 = 0.04 (T) and T1 = 300 (K). As is clear from this figure, the values [(ωNL)11/(ωL)11] decrease with increasing the ratio (h/a).
If the length of plate (a) is considered to be constant, the rate of variation of the ratio [(ωNL)11/(ωL)11] is high for low thicknesses and for the higher thicknesses, this rate of variation decreases. Also, according to Fig. 9, [(ωNL)11/(ωL)11] ratio decreases by increasing the constant n̂.

sections.heading: 7.2.7 Investigation the effects of mechanical and electrical length scale parameters
sections.text:
In Fig. 10, the variations of the dimensionless natural and nonlinear frequencies are plotted in terms of the dimensionless parameter (h/ l) for different values of the magnetic flux density in the first four vibrational modes. The quantity (l) is the length scale parameter associated with the strain gradient and has a length dimension.
In this model, V0 = 0 (V), n̂ = 10, h = 10 (nm) and T1 = 300 (K) have been assumed. By increasing parameter (h/ l), the natural dimensionless frequencies decrease. Also, the variations rate of the natural dimensionless frequency decreases for high values of the (h/ l) ratios in higher vibrational modes.
Figure 11 shows the first nonlinear dimensionless frequency variations in terms of length scale parameter associated with the polarization gradient (β) for different boundary conditions. In order to obtained the results, V0 = 0 (v), B0 = 0.04 (T), h = 10 (nm) and T2 = 300 (K) are assumed.
As shown in Fig. 11, the nonlinear frequencies of the nano-plate increase with increasing the β values. For low values of β, the rate of frequency variation is high and it decreases with increasing the β values.
According to previous studies, electrical polarization decreases with increasing β [35]. By increasing the electrical dipoles generated in the nano-plate, its equivalent rigidity and natural frequencies increase.
Also, referring the previous studies, it can be found that for the high values of β, the rate of electric polarization variation decreases [35]. By decreasing the variation rate of the electrical polarization, the rate of change in the rigidity and the rate of change in the natural frequencies of nano-plate decrease. Therefore, variation rate of nano-plate natural frequency is more for lower values of β and is less for its higher values.

sections.heading: 8 Conclusions
sections.text:
In this study, using new formulation based on themodified flexoelectric theory, the free and nonlinear vibrations of functionally graded nano-plate under electric, thermal andmagnetic fields have been investigated. The nanoplate motion equations and boundary conditions were determined using the Hamilton’s principle.
Finally, in order to determine the natural frequencies for the first four vibrational modes, couple nonlinear differential equations were solved using Galerkin’s method and multiple-scale method. The results of this study are presented for two modes of direct and inverse flexoelectric effects, as well as for different boundary conditions, and are presented in the figures and tables given in the previous sections. The results of this research are briefly summarized as follows:
1- Considering the flexoelectric effect, the nano-plate will have higher natural frequencies. 2- The elastic modulus and natural frequencies of the nano-plate will increase by increasing the index of the
functionally graded model. 3- According to the given plots and tables, parameters such as the index of the functionally graded model of
material (n̂), electric potential, thermal loading andmagnetic loading affect the values of natural frequencies. Due to the order of the impact magnitude, the parameters such as electrical potential, magnetic flux density, index related to functionally graded behavior and thermal loading influence the nano-plate free vibrations, respectively. Therefore, electrical potential has the highest effect and the thermal loading has the least effect on the natural frequencies of the nano-plate. 4. Increasing the magnetic flux density passing from the nano-plate along the thickness direction, the natural frequencies of the nano-plate increase. Also, the variation rate of natural frequency in high magnitude of the magnetic flux density increases, and in smaller quantities, the variation rate of the natural frequencies decreases. 5. In the presence of a flexoelectric effect, the magnetic flux density could have a greater effect on the vibrational behavior of the nano-plate. Therefore, considering the flexoelectric phenomenon, the static magnetic flux density can play a significant role as a frequency controller of the nano-plate. 6. The natural frequencies of the nano-plate can be adjusted and controlled by varying the flexoelectric coefficient, the applied potential and themagnetic flux density. Therefore, these factorswill play an important role in the design, manufacture and performance improvement of the flexoelectric nano-plates that employed in sensors and actuators. 7. Due to the very large natural frequencies presented in the figures of the previous section in the range of GHz, then these types of structures can be used for the design and construction of the high-frequency oscillators.

metadata.abstractText: In the present study, a continuous-based thermo-electromechanic model has been developed by the Kirchhoff plate’s theory and the modified flexoelectric theory in order to study the size-dependent nonlinear free vibration of functionally graded flexoelectric nano-plate under the magnetic field. Using the Hamilton’s principle and variation method, the nonlinear governing differential equations of the nano-plate and their associated boundary conditions have been extracted and the governing equations solved by using Galerkin’s and perturbation methods. The electromechanical coupling (electromechanical stress) in the internal energy function causes nonlinearity in the governing equations. The applied magnetic field is a type of external static field along with the nano-plate thickness. The natural frequencies and related mode shapes have been determined in two modes of direct and inverse flexoelectric effects. Also, the effects of such factors as length scale parameters, geometric parameters, thermal, magnetic and electrical loadings were investigated. In the presence of flexoelectric effect, the results showed that the dependence of electromechanical behavior of the structure on size is found to be significant in nanoscales. Regarding the application of this type of nano-plate in the oscillators and considering the flexoelectric effect, the applied potential difference can play an important role in adjusting and controlling the frequency.
